articles.headline: For X-Rated, a Domain of Their Own
articles.snippet: The agency that governs Internet addresses agreed to move forward on the dot-xxx proposal from an adult entertainment site.
articles.abstract: The agency that governs Internet addresses agreed to move forward on the dot-xxx proposal from an adult entertainment site.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  What if the Web held a sex party and no one showed up?

articles.headline: Iraq’s Ancient Ruins Face New Looting
articles.snippet: Thousands of important sites have been left unprotected, allowing what officials say is a resumption of illegal excavations.
articles.abstract: Thousands of important sites have been left unprotected, allowing what officials say is a resumption of illegal excavations.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHAHIR, Iraq  The looting of Iraq’s ancient ruins is thriving again. This time it is not a result of the “stuff happens” chaos that followed the American invasion in 2003, but rather the bureaucratic indifference of Iraq’s newly sovereign government.

articles.headline: Goldman Must Pay Some Bayou Losses
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs was ordered to pay $20.58 million to creditors of a failed hedge fund to settle claims that the bank helped the fund perpetrate a Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs was ordered to pay $20.58 million to creditors of a failed hedge fund to settle claims that the bank helped the fund perpetrate a Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs has been ordered to pay $20.58 million to creditors of a failed hedge fund to settle claims that the bank helped the fund perpetrate a Ponzi scheme.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Gretchen Morgenson

articles.headline: A Chinese Factory Outsources Worker Dorms
articles.snippet: Under scrutiny after several suicides at its factories in China, Foxconn Technology, a supplier to Apple, Dell and Hewlett-Packard, has decided to stop operating dormitories for workers.
articles.abstract: Under scrutiny after several suicides at its factories in China, Foxconn Technology, a supplier to Apple, Dell and Hewlett-Packard, has decided to stop operating dormitories for workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Under intense scrutiny after several suicides at its factories in southern China this year, Foxconn Technology, a major supplier to Apple, Dell and Hewlett-Packard, has decided to stop operating its own dormitories for workers.

articles.headline: Moratorium Won’t Reduce Drilling Risks
articles.snippet: Facing the dangers inherent in deepwater drilling for natural gas and oil is preferable to delaying the activity.
articles.abstract: Facing the dangers inherent in deepwater drilling for natural gas and oil is preferable to delaying the activity.
articles.lead_paragraph: “This case asks whether the federal government’s imposition of a general moratorium on deepwater drilling for oil in the Gulf of Mexico was imposed contrary to law. Before the Court is the plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction. For the following reasons, the motion is GRANTED."

articles.headline: Icelander’s Campaign Is a Joke, Until He’s Elected
articles.snippet: A comedian tapped voters’ anger over the country’s economy, promising free towels and a Disneyland.
articles.abstract: A comedian tapped voters’ anger over the country’s economy, promising free towels and a Disneyland.
articles.lead_paragraph: REYKJAVIK, Iceland  A polar bear display for the zoo. Free towels at public swimming pools. A “drug-free Parliament by 2020.” Iceland’s Best Party, founded in December by a comedian, Jon Gnarr, to satirize his country’s political system, ran a campaign that was one big joke. Or was it?

articles.headline: New Rules May Affect Every Corner of JPMorgan
articles.snippet: In ways subtle and profound, new financial rules could change the way business will be done for years to come at big banks like JPMorgan.
articles.abstract: In ways subtle and profound, new financial rules could change the way business will be done for years to come at big banks like JPMorgan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not since the Great Depression, when the mighty House of Morgan was cleaved in two, have Washington lawmakers rewritten the rules for Wall Street as extensively as they did on Friday.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Andrew Martin

articles.headline: Louisiana Wants U.S. Help, and Its Own Way
articles.snippet: Gov. Bobby Jindal has been critical of BP and the government in the spill, but interviews suggest that Louisiana has often disregarded its own response plans.
articles.abstract: Gov. Bobby Jindal has been critical of BP and the government in the spill, but interviews suggest that Louisiana has often disregarded its own response plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  For weeks, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana has attacked BP and the Coast Guard for not having adequate plans and resources to battle the oil spill.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and John Collins Rudolf

articles.headline: Genetically Altered Salmon Get Closer to the Table
articles.snippet: The first engineered animal for people to eat, salmon that grow faster than normal, may be approved by the F.D.A.
articles.abstract: The first engineered animal for people to eat, salmon that grow faster than normal, may be approved by the F.D.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is seriously considering whether to approve the first genetically engineered animal that people would eat  salmon that can grow at twice the normal rate.

articles.headline: Kagan Hearings May Have Wider Focus
articles.snippet: At her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Elena Kagan may well be a supporting player in a drama featuring two men not even there.
articles.abstract: At her Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Elena Kagan may well be a supporting player in a drama featuring two men not even there.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  At Supreme Court confirmation hearings, the nominee is usually the star. But Elena Kagan may well be a supporting player in a drama featuring two men not even there: President Obama and Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.

articles.headline: Strong Enough for Tough Stains?
articles.snippet: When it comes to cutting huge financial institutions down to size, the Dodd-Frank bill fails completely. But it fares better on other counts.
articles.abstract: When it comes to cutting huge financial institutions down to size, the Dodd-Frank bill fails completely. But it fares better on other counts.
articles.lead_paragraph: OUR nation’s Congressional machinery was humming last week as legislators reconciled the differences between the labyrinthine financial reforms proposed by the Senate and the House and emerged early Friday morning with a voluminous new law in hand. They christened it the Dodd-Frank bill, after the heads of the Senate Banking and House Financial Services Committees who drove the process toward the finish line.

articles.headline: The Idea Incubator Goes to Campus
articles.snippet: Proof-of-concept centers are giving universities the money and other support to take unproven ideas and make them appeal to venture capitalists.
articles.abstract: Proof-of-concept centers are giving universities the money and other support to take unproven ideas and make them appeal to venture capitalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOUGLAS P. HART, a professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who sold his last start-up for a tidy $95 million, is already on to his next big thing.

articles.headline: Overture to Taliban Jolts Afghan Minorities
articles.snippet: President Hamid Karzai’s drive to strike a deal with Taliban leaders is causing unease among Afghanistan’s minorities, who suffered the most during their rule.
articles.abstract: President Hamid Karzai’s drive to strike a deal with Taliban leaders is causing unease among Afghanistan’s minorities, who suffered the most during their rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  The drive by President Hamid Karzai to strike a deal with Taliban leaders and their Pakistani backers is causing deep unease in Afghanistan’s minority communities, who fought the Taliban the longest and suffered the most during their rule.

articles.headline: When Capitalism Meets Cannabis
articles.snippet: Colorado legalized medical marijuana in 2000, but a recent bill could force amateurs out of the business.
articles.abstract: Colorado legalized medical marijuana in 2000, but a recent bill could force amateurs out of the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo.

articles.headline: On Finance Bill, Lobbying Shifts to Regulations
articles.snippet: Partisans on both sides will get a second chance to influence the outcome as agencies fill in the blanks in lawmakers’ vague financial legislation.
articles.abstract: Partisans on both sides will get a second chance to influence the outcome as agencies fill in the blanks in lawmakers’ vague financial legislation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Well before Congress reached agreement on the details of its financial overhaul legislation, industry lobbyists and consumer advocates started preparing for the next battle: influencing the creation of several hundred new rules and regulations.

articles.headline: One Battalion’s Wrenching Deployment to Afghanistan
articles.snippet: For the next year, the First Battalion, 87th Infantry of the 10th Mountain Division will be in Afghanistan, part of the additional 30,000 troops at the backbone of President Obama’s plan for ending the war.
articles.abstract: For the next year, the First Battalion, 87th Infantry of the 10th Mountain Division will be in Afghanistan, part of the additional 30,000 troops at the backbone of President Obama’s plan for ending the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pvt. Johnnie Stevenson spent his final hours at Fort Drum alone, trying to put his game face on. He played some Ludacris on his iPod, then turned it off. He unpacked his 72-hour bag, then repacked it. Did he have enough toothpaste and spare socks? Had he paid his bills? Was he ready for war? For a year?

articles.headline: Pakistan’s Plan on Afghan Peace Leaves U.S. Wary
articles.snippet: President Obama and Leon A. Panetta, the C.I.A. director, expressed skepticism that the Taliban would be amenable to reconciliation and laying down their arms.
articles.abstract: President Obama and Leon A. Panetta, the C.I.A. director, expressed skepticism that the Taliban would be amenable to reconciliation and laying down their arms.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama and the director of the Central Intelligence Agency both reacted with skepticism on Sunday about the prospects for an Afghanistan peace deal pushed by Pakistan between the Afghan government and some Taliban militants.

articles.headline: World Leaders Agree on Timetable for Cutting Deficits
articles.snippet: The Group of 20 countries endorsed a goal of cutting deficits by 2013, despite concern by the U.S. that reducing spending too quickly might set back the fragile global recovery.
articles.abstract: The Group of 20 countries endorsed a goal of cutting deficits by 2013, despite concern by the U.S. that reducing spending too quickly might set back the fragile global recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO  Leaders of the world’s biggest economies agreed Sunday on a timetable for cutting deficits and halting the growth of their debt, but also acknowledged the need to move carefully so that reductions in spending did not set back the fragile global recovery.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: Heedlessly Hijacking Content
articles.snippet: Rolling Stone made news with the McChrystal piece it commissioned, edited, fact-checked, printed and distributed. Too bad it didn’t get to publish it first.
articles.abstract: Rolling Stone made news with the McChrystal piece it commissioned, edited, fact-checked, printed and distributed. Too bad it didn’t get to publish it first.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal was not the only one who had a tough week at the office.

articles.headline: At Summit, Banks Avoid New Global Regulations
articles.snippet: A new set of global rules on capital and liquidity are to be finished at the next G-20 summit talks in November, but it could be years before they take effect.
articles.abstract: A new set of global rules on capital and liquidity are to be finished at the next G-20 summit talks in November, but it could be years before they take effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO  Giant banks, while bracing for a wave of tougher regulation in Washington, will not have to face a new set of global rules on capital and liquidity anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Jackie Calmes

articles.headline: BP Loses Trading-Floor Swagger in Energy Markets
articles.snippet: The future of BP’s trading unit is uncertain as oil spill costs mount and rival firms try to lure away traders.
articles.abstract: The future of BP’s trading unit is uncertain as oil spill costs mount and rival firms try to lure away traders.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems like Wall Street at its worst: a cowboy on the trading floor plots to corner a market, and gets caught.

articles.headline: Labor’s New Critics: Old Allies in Elected Office
articles.snippet: Republicans have often railed against public employees’ pay and benefits, but now friends of labor are joining in.
articles.abstract: Republicans have often railed against public employees’ pay and benefits, but now friends of labor are joining in.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRENTON  Stephen M. Sweeney, the president of the State Senate here, glowered with disgust as he described how one New Jersey town paid out nearly $1 million to four retiring police officers for their unused sick days and vacation time.

articles.headline: A Magazine Back on a Roll
articles.snippet: Rolling Stone’s circulation has increased as it takes on coverage of the financial crisis and the war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Rolling Stone’s circulation has increased as it takes on coverage of the financial crisis and the war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its early days in the 1960s and ’70s, Rolling Stone was a chronicle of the counterculture where a generation of young people came to find political coverage that spoke to their disaffection.

articles.headline: From CNBC Business Journalist to Critic of Bankers on MSNBC
articles.snippet: Until fairly recently, Dylan Ratigan hosted a stock-picking show. Now he rails against the “vampire” banks who “have assumed control of our government.”
articles.abstract: Until fairly recently, Dylan Ratigan hosted a stock-picking show. Now he rails against the “vampire” banks who “have assumed control of our government.”
articles.lead_paragraph: On most cable newscasts, the people who are writing new financial regulations are called congressmen. But on “The Dylan Ratigan Show” on MSNBC, some are called “banksters.”

articles.headline: Technology Innovator’s Mobile Move
articles.snippet: SRI International, whose work led to the computer mouse, has set its sights on the mobile phone and Web market.
articles.abstract: SRI International, whose work led to the computer mouse, has set its sights on the mobile phone and Web market.
articles.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif.  The film “2001: A Space Odyssey” presents a dramatic vision of the future, where sentient robots double as secretaries, performing daily tasks and simple services for their human masters.

articles.headline: Broadband Availability to Expand
articles.snippet: A presidential memorandum aims to make available for auction some 500 megahertz of spectrum.
articles.abstract: A presidential memorandum aims to make available for auction some 500 megahertz of spectrum.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is seeking to nearly double the wireless communications spectrum available for commercial use over the next 10 years, an effort that could greatly enhance the ability of consumers to send and receive video and data with smartphones and other hand-held devices.

articles.headline: Robert C. Byrd, a Pillar of the Senate, Dies at 92
articles.snippet: Elected to a record nine terms in the Senate, Mr. Byrd championed the legislative branch and brought huge amounts of federal money to West Virginia.
articles.abstract: Elected to a record nine terms in the Senate, Mr. Byrd championed the legislative branch and brought huge amounts of federal money to West Virginia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert C. Byrd served 51 years in the United States Senate, longer than anyone else in history, and with his six years in the House of Representatives, he was the longest-serving member of Congress. But it was how he used that record tenure that made him a pillar of Capitol Hill  fighting, often with florid words, for the primacy of the legislative branch of government and building, always with canny political skills, a modern West Virginia with vast amounts of federal money.

articles.headline: Justices Take Broad View of Business Method Patents
articles.snippet: A system of hedging weather-related costs is denied a patent, but the Supreme Court declined to eliminate patent protection for all business methods and processes.
articles.abstract: A system of hedging weather-related costs is denied a patent, but the Supreme Court declined to eliminate patent protection for all business methods and processes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The door to the patent office should remain open to those who create methods of doing business, the Supreme Court said in a long-awaited decision announced on Monday.

articles.headline: Justices Uphold Sarbanes-Oxley Act
articles.snippet: A ruling will change only the removal of members of the accounting oversight board created under the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley law.
articles.abstract: A ruling will change only the removal of members of the accounting oversight board created under the 2002 Sarbanes-Oxley law.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first group established by Congress to regulate the accounting industry survived a constitutional challenge on Monday, emerging only with its members having a little less job security.
articles.byline: By Floyd Norris and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: Justices Extend Firearm Rights in 5-to-4 Ruling
articles.snippet: A 5-4 ruling on the Second Amendment is a symbolic victory for gun rights advocates, but its short-term practical impact is unclear.
articles.abstract: A 5-4 ruling on the Second Amendment is a symbolic victory for gun rights advocates, but its short-term practical impact is unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Second Amendment’s guarantee of an individual right to bear arms applies to state and local gun control laws, the Supreme Court ruled Monday in a 5-to-4 decision.
